item.description: What happens when we have to make real-world construction match unrealistic mathematical models, that we happen to know how to simulate?

item.title: They don't make 'em like that any more: how the Vectrex almost revolutionized video gaming
item.description: The Vectrex used an entirely novel display technology that was superior to the TV-based displays of the time. Why didnt it catch on?

item.title: Using Apache Camel to implement an IRC bot
item.description: Camel's IRC support makes it relatively easy to implement an IRC conversation agent, that can process IRC messages and produce responses.

item.title: Adventures with Artix
item.description: Artix is a low-resource Linux that can be configured to run well on old, low-powered computer hardware. In this article, I describe my first attempts at setting it up.

item.title: C development for Linux without a standard library
item.description: There are relatively few good reasons for writing C code without using a standard C library. However, doing so provides valuable insights into how compilers and operating systems work, and is worth doing if only for its educational value.

item.title: The nuts and bolts of anonymous inner classes in Java
item.description: Many of the standard Java APIs make extensive use of anonymous inner classes, to provide features that in other language would be provided using lambda functions or closures. However, anonymous inner classes have limitations that many developers find difficult to understand and to work with. This article explains why this is the case.

item.title: Command-line hacking: countdown timer
item.description: Using Linux date calculations to displaying a running countdown time in the terminal.

item.title: How Linux home directory encryption works
item.description: Encryption of home directories is out of favour in modern Linux distributions, but it offers some compelling advantages over the alternatives, if used with care.

item.title: Rudiments of Java concurrency control, part 1
item.description: The first part in a series on concurrency management in multi-threaded Java programs. This article deals with monitor objects and their use for demarcation of non-concurrent sections.

item.title: They don't make 'em like that any more: Borland Turbo Pascal 7
item.description: Why half a million people learned to program in Pascal, when you'd think they had no earthly reason to.

item.title: Some thoughts on using a small cellphone as a media player
item.description: Modern portable media players are generally smartphones without an antenna. So why not repurpose a real smartphone as a media player?

item.title: Yet another desktop Raspberry Pi media player
item.description: Using a Raspberry Pi as a media player is by no means a new idea. However, using one as a self-contained hifi component is not common, and requires a bit of work.

item.title: Making tab-and-slot boxes for electronic prototypes. Or: how I stopped worrying and learned to love the laser
item.description: Some thoughts on my first experiments with the design of electronics enclosures for laser cutting.

item.title: Getting started with Kafka Streams, part 2
item.description: Following on from my article on the rudiments of the Kafka Streams API, this one introduces stateful operations like counting and aggregation.

item.title: Getting started with Kafka Streams
item.description: Kafka Streams is a Java library and framework for creating applications that consume, process, and return Apache Kafka messages. This article provides a tutorial about implementing a very basic Streams application.

item.title: They don't make them like that any more: Garmin Nuvi 300
item.description: One of the earliest mass-market car satnav units, the Garmin Nuvi 300 still has features that modern devices lack. Why is that?

item.title: Predicting eclipses with clockwork
item.description: We're used to computing devices being electronic. But what can we do with a purely mechanical approach? This article looks at how eclipse prediction might have worked in the Antikythera Mechanism, c.2300 years ago.

item.title: RSS feed
item.description: About RSS support on this website

item.title: Command-line hacking: calculating the phase of the Moon
item.description: How to use Bash shell arithmetic, along with the 'date' utilty, to calculate the phase of the Moon on a particlar day.

item.title: They don't make 'em like that any more: Blackberry Bold 9700
item.description: The Bold 9700 was a premium cellphone from a company at the top of its game. Does it merit the fawning reviews it collected in 2009?

item.title: Kafka Connect from the ground up, part II
item.description: This article describes what I think is the simplest possible Kafka Connect on Strimzi -- the Kubernetes implementation of Kafka. If follows from an earlier article about using Kafka Connect on bare metal.

item.title: Kafka Connect from the ground up
item.description: This article describes what I think is the simplest possible Kafka Connect set-up, using a single-node Kafka installation. To ensure that the principles are clear, I use only a text editor and command-line tools to run the Connect infrastructure and deploy the connector.

item.title: Powering a Raspberry Pi from an attached Waveshare USB HAT
item.description: Attaching high-capacity hard disks has always been a bit of a problem for the Raspberry Pi. In this article I describe a simple modification to a Waveshare USB HAT, that allows it to power both the attached drives and also the Pi itself.

item.title: Converting push-button events to keyboard events in the Raspberry Pi
item.description: The Raspberry Pi has a bunch of GPIO pins we can use to connect push-buttons. But how do we interface push-buttons to an application that expects only keyboard input?

item.title: Rolling your own minimal embedded Linux for the Raspberry Pi -- part one: booting to a root shell
item.description: This article is part of a series on building a custom Linux installation for a Raspberry Pi-based appliance. It explains how to make a bootable SD card with Pi firmware, a Linux kernel, and a shell. It's about as minimal as a Linux system can be.

item.title: Why the grammer snobs have it all wrong about the apostrophe
item.description: Was there ever a golden age of the apostrophe, when everybody used it the same? No.

item.title: They don't make 'em like that any more: Archos 605 media player/recorder
item.description: You think Apple was an innovator in the world of personal media players? Think again.

item.title: ActiveMQ/Artemis or Kafka for Java messaging?
item.description: ActiveMQ and Kafka are both open-source, Java-based, message brokers with applications in inter-process communication. But can they be used interchangeably?

item.title: They don't make them like that any more: the slide rule
item.description: This simple analog computer has served humanity for more than four centuries. Shouldn't we try to preserve it?

item.title: Is your fitness watch lying to you?
item.description: People are increasingly using smart watches and fitness watches for tracking health metrics. Is it wise to do so? (Short answer: probably not.)

item.title: Some thoughts on always-on OLED displays on smart watches
item.description: Why an expensive smart watch is still less good than a cheap Timex, when it comes to telling the time.

item.title: Command-line hacking: displaying system temperature
item.description: Using simple file and string handling techniques in the Bash shell.

item.title: Does the use of custom Android ROMs improve or worsen security?
item.description: This question is not particularly easy to answer, but understanding the implications helps.

item.title: They don't make 'em like that any more: NVIDIA Shield K1 tablet
item.description: Despite its low initial price, the Shield K1 continues to put modern Android tablets to shame.

item.title: Snake oil: 4K displays on smartphones
item.description: The screen resolution of smartphones has increased dramatically over the last ten years. Have we reached a point where further improvement is just a waste of money?

item.title: What you give up, when you opt out of the surveillance economy
item.description: Is it possible to live without Google and the like, and still use modern, portable computing devices? I still don't know.

item.title: Adventures with RC2014, Z80, and CP/M
item.description: This is a landing page for my various articles on building a period-appropriate CP/M system using the RC2014 bus.

item.title: Designing a dual 5V-to-RS232 serial level converter for the RC2014
item.description: Using an RC2014-based retrocomputer with genuine RS232 peripherals requires support for voltage level conversion. Although converter modules are inexpensive and widely available, I wanted to design something that would plug into an RC2014 backplane, just for neatness.

item.title: They don't make 'em like that any more: The Philips Pronto remote control
item.description: The Pronto offers a salutary lesson in how an excellent product can die, leaving a gaping hole in the market that nobody wants to fill.

item.title: They don't make 'em like that any more: a paean to the Cowon D2 DAB
item.description: The Cowon D2 DAB was a media player ahead of its time. There was nothing like it in 2005, and there still isn't.

item.title: CP/M resources
item.description: A landing page for my various CP/M articles and utilities.

item.title: Getting to grips with JMS shared subscriptions
item.description: Shared subscriptions are a 'new' feature in JMS, that seems to be poorly understood, particularly in a clustered environment. In this article, I explain how shared subscriptions are supposed to work, and what the implications are for load sharing and fault tolerance.

item.title: Adding a floppy disk controller to my RC2014 Z80 system
item.description: No 80s computer is complete without the chucka-chucka-chucka sound of a floppy disk drive doing its thing.

item.title: Using flash memory as non-volatile storage on the Pi Pico microcontroller
item.description: The Pi Pico is an impressive microcontroller for its size and cost, but it lacks specific non-volatile memory. This article explains how to use the program flash ROM for that purpose.

item.title: Constructing and programming a YM2149 sound board my RC2014 Z80 system
item.description: An 80's-style 8-bit computer has to be cable of making 80's 8-bit sound. In this article I describe adding a sound board to my RC2014 system.

item.title: Updating, building, and flashing RomWBW on an SC130 CP/M system
item.description: A step-by-step guide to building and installing a modified version of the RomWBW firmware on a CP/M Z80 board.

item.title: Exchanging files between an SC130 CP/M board and a Linux system
item.description: This article describes a couple of methods for sharing data and code between a CP/M system with RomWBW BIOS and a Linux system.

item.title: Some thoughts on a DS1302 real-time clock board for RC2014/Z80 and CP/M
item.description: Constructing and programming a real-time clock board for my Z80 CP/M system

item.title: Using a CP/M machine to log into a Linux server using an RS232 connection
item.description: Because -- why not?

item.title: Serial device mapping in CP/M
item.description: CP/M only recognized four serial devices. How did application cope when more than four serial ports were installed?

item.title: The vexed problem of generating delays in a CP/M program
item.description: CP/M has no timing or delay functions, because CP/M never stipulated that compatible hardware have any kind of clock. So how do we implement short (fractions of a second) delays in a CP/M program?

item.title: Is Collapse OS really a practical proposition?
item.description: Is it really possible to design an operating system for a computer built from scavenged parts after civilization has failed?

item.title: Getting back into C programming for CP/M -- part 2
item.description: Using the 1989 HI-TECH C compiler on CP/M, and some general observations about CP/M programming with real hardware.

item.title: Using Keycloak for authentication with Apache Artemis: part 2
item.description: This article continues my explanation of using Keycloak as an authentication provider for Apache Artemis, by showing how to use a bearer token to authenticate a JMS client.

item.title: A self-contained CP/M computer based on the Z80 Playground
item.description: This article describes how to create a self-contained CP/M-based microcomputer using a Z80 single-board computer, a Raspberry Pi Zero, and some assorted electrical parts.

item.title: Why does my Raspberry Pi project keep displaying the 'lightning bolt' undervoltage indicator?
item.description: The Raspberry Pi is widely used as part of a more complex electronic project or construction. There's a misconception that such a construction can be powered from the same cheap, nasty USB charger that is suitable to power a Pi on its own. Attempting to do this often leads to undervoltage situations. This article explains why, and what constructors can do about it.

item.title: Using an Oracle database as storage for the Apache Artemis message broker -- part 2
item.description: This article is the second on my series on using the Oracle database as the message data store for the Apache Artemis message broker. In it, I describe the database schema, and how it supports messaging operations.

item.title: Using an Oracle database as storage for the Apache Artemis message broker -- part 1
item.description: This article describes the fundamentals of setting up the Apache Artemis message broker to use an Oracle database as the message data store.

item.title: Using the Qpid Proton C++ library to understand AMQP
item.description: AMQP is not a trivially-straightforward protocol to understand, but it's necessary to get to grips with it to write effective software that uses the Qpid Proton AMQP library. Perhaps one of the simplest ways to understand AMQP is to use Proton's own packet-tracing features, as this article explains.

item.title: What exactly is 'saturation'?
item.description: Most image editing applications provide a 'saturation' adjustment; some provide adjustments of 'brilliance', 'chroma', and other things. This article explains what these terms actually mean.

item.title: Yet another Darktable/Lightroom comparison
item.description: Darktable isn't supposed to be an alternative to Adobe Lightroom, but many people hope to use it as one. After all, Darktable's (free) pricing is very appealing. Here are my views on whether a move to Darktable makes sense.

item.title: Using media keys in a Linux console application
item.description: Mapping keyboard keys to key codes on Linux is well-documented for the graphical desktop. But what about console applications on embedded Linux systems? There's not much documentation in this area.

item.title: Differential equations: how does separation of variables really work?
item.description: 'Separation of variables' is one of the first methods usually taught to math and engineering students for solving differential equations, and yet the method as taught is mathematically very sloppy. That's not to say it doesn't work, but rather that it isn't made clear why it works, and whether similar methods will work elsewhere. This article attempts to treat the subject with a bit of mathematical rigour. We end up exactly where we started but, perhaps, with a bit more insight.

item.title: Using the Linux framebuffer in C/C++ -- just the essentials (part 2)
item.description: This article continues my original framebuffer "just the essentials" article, by describing how to handle less straightforward framebuffer configurations.

item.title: Using the Linux framebuffer in C/C++ -- just the essentials
item.description: The absolute minimum information needed to start using the Linux framebuffer as a graphical display in C/C++ applications.

item.title: pico-photo-clock: an easy-to-construct Pi Pico desktop photo clock
item.description: This article describes how to construct a desktop photo clock using a Raspberry Pi Pico and some solder-free peripherals.

item.title: Using the Maxim DS3231 I2C real-time clock in C on the Raspberry Pi Pico
item.description: The Maxim DS3231 I2C real-time clock is a reasonably accurate, inexpensive device, that is easy to interface to the Raspberry Pi Pico.

item.title: Using ImageMagick to generate anti-aliased bitmap fonts for a microcontroller's LCD display
item.description: This article describes how to generate and use compressed, anti-aliased font data, for use in a microcontroller application.

item.title: The Pi Pico, two years on
item.description: I've been using the Raspberry Pi Pico for embedded projects for the last two years or so. What do I think of it now?

item.title: Some thoughts on the Waveshare 3.5-inch LCD/SD module for the Raspberry Pi Pico
item.description: This is a versatile touchscreen display module with a strikingly low cost. But is it any good?

item.title: Why 'int x = 0' is uninitialized data to the GNU C compiler
item.description: An oddity of the GCC C compiler that can lead to strange results, particularly in an embedded application

item.title: Raspberry Pi Pico: loading code into RAM and running it -- part 2
item.description: This is the second of (at least) two articles on loading and running arbitrary executable code into RAM on the Pico, and running it.

item.title: Raspberry Pi Pico: loading code into RAM and running it -- part 1
item.description: This is the first of (at least) two articles on loading and running arbitrary executable code into RAM on the Pico, and running it.

item.title: Some thoughts on using a USB keyboard with the Raspberry Pi Pico
item.description: The Pi Pico has USB host support, and can work with a USB keyboard. Although there are some programming examples, the general approach to programming USB host operations is not well documented.

item.title: Using the rdkafka library to integrate a C program with Kafka messaging
item.description: This article provides a brief overview of the rdkafka library, illustrated by a simple test application in C.

item.title: Why synchronous write speed is likely to be the limiting factor in message broker throughput
item.description: Administrators of middleware message brokers often struggle to get adequate throughput. A lot of time and effort can be wasted, if the administrator doesn't appreciate the crucial role of synchronous disk writes in these installations.

item.title: Why your cheap mains inverter could kill you
item.description: A mains inverter is a very useful device, but inexpensive models create significant electrical safety hazards. This article explains why.

item.title: Using Quarkus to provide a REST interface to a message broker
item.description: Using a Camel application based on Quarkus to provide a way to route messages to and from a message broker using HTTP requests

item.title: Comparing a natively-compiled Java webservice with C
item.description: Implementing a webservice in C and Java, to see which performs better in terms of throughput and resource usage.

item.title: Is dithering necessary when reducing the number of bits per sample in an audio waveform?
item.description: The use of dithering when mastering a CD is well-established, and its effectiveness is rarely challenged. But is it beneficial in other circumstances when we need to reduce the bit depth of an audio stream?

item.title: The costs and benefits of software pulse-width modulation on the Raspberry Pi
item.description: The Raspberry Pi doesn't offer much in the way of analog outputs, or even hardware controlled PWM. Software-controlled PWM is an alternative in some applications, but it needs to be used carefully, if inefficiencies are to be avoided.

item.title: Using an HD44780 LCD display module with the Raspberry Pi, from the ground up
item.description: In this article I explain how to construct, and program in C, an I2C interface to the popular HD44780 LCD display for the Raspberry Pi. Between the article and the accompanying source code, no technical details are concealed: I present the complete hardware design and every line of C code needed to operate it.

item.title: Monitoring an INA219 chip in a Raspberry Pi battery-backed power supply
item.description: Many battery-backed power supplies for the Raspberry Pi, and similar systems, use the INA219 current/voltage monitor IC. This device has an I2C interface by which the Pi can determine the battery voltage and current, and estimate the charge level and run-time. This article describes how to write C code that interacts with the INA219.

item.title: Getting reasonably robust proximity measurements from an ultrasonic sensor on the Raspberry Pi
item.description: The HC-SR04 proximity sensor is an inexpensive and widely-used ultrasonic device. Connecting one to an HC-SR04 to a Raspberry Pi is a common educational exercise, but getting accurate, repeatable measurement of distance in a real application is actually quite difficult. This article explains why, and what can be done to improve matters.

item.title: Using a shift register to control eight digital outputs with three GPIO lines on the Raspberry Pi
item.description: A simple and inexpensive shift register can be used to increase the digital output provision of a Raspberry Pi or microcontroller. This well-know technique is easy to apply, but has some limitations that require careful consideration.

item.title: How flat-earthers use misrepresentations of scale to promote their ideas
item.description: Misrepresentations of scale are common in the literature of organizations that seek to deceive. However, it's sometimes difficult, or unhelpful, to draw diagrams to scale. This article tries to explain the difference between benign and pernicious distortions of scale. I'm picking on the flat-earthers for the purposes of illustration, but the presentational devices they use are common in business and politics as well.

item.title: Why "RMS watts" is a useless measure of power
item.description: It's common for hifi amplifiers and speakers to have a power rating expressed in terms of "RMS watts". Although RMS amplitude is an important concept in electronic engineering, it's meaningless here, and should be avoided.

item.title: Calculus of variations: a lunchbreak guide
item.description: The calculus of variations is a branch of mathematics that deals with finding functions that optimize systems. Although calculus of variations has its origins in the 18th century, it is still not widely taught, either to science or engineering students. This brief guide intends to explain the basic principles, with a fully-worked example, in something that can be read in about an hour.

item.title: Sorting files and directories on a FAT-formatted USB memory stick
item.description: Many portable and automotive media players accept USB memory sticks or SD cards containing audio files. Very often, these players have no sorting logic, and display files and directories in the arbitrary order they appear in the filesystem. This article describes how to sort a FAT filesystem using Linux utilities, to make playback more convenient.

item.title: A review of the Leak Stereo 130 and CDT
item.description: A number of reviews of the Leak Stereo 130 and CDT can be found online, but they are short on practical details. I've been using mine eight hours a day for several months; this is what I think of them.

item.title: Why is there a vinyl revival?
item.description: Why are sales of vinyl records increasing, when digital streaming services provide access to almost any recording ever made, in superior technical quality?

item.title: Does it matter how we rip audio CDs?
item.description: Copying an audio CD -- perhaps to a portable music player -- is a common enough operation. There are strong opinions on how to do this, and what software to use. But does it really make any difference? Or is one bit the same as any other?

item.title: Is "high resolution" audio really worth the effort?
item.description: The availability of "better than CD" audio recordings is driving, and being driven by, more expensive and elaborate audio hardware, even in the consumer market. Is this a good thing?

item.title: Why you can't improve your hi-fi system by upgrading the mains cable
item.description: You really can't improve your hi-fi system with a fancy mains cable. But why? And why do people think you can?

item.title: Do different CD transports sound different?
item.description: Bits are bits, right? If a CD transport just sends digital data to a DAC, is it even possible that different transports sound different?

item.title: Snake oil: balanced headphones
item.description: Do balanced headphones provide an improvement in sound quality over conventional, single-ended designs? Unlikely. In fact, the increased complexity of these designs may actually reduce the accuracy of sound reproduction.

item.title: Why your vintage turntable could kill you
item.description: Vintage vinyl records ought, perhaps, to be played on a vintage turntable. Although such appliances are still widely available, and can work well, they fall short of contemporary electrical safety standards.

item.title: A skeptic's guide to headphones
item.description: Understanding the advantages and disadvantages of the various types of headphone that are currently available, without all the "audiophile" silliness.

item.title: Are Flatpak, et al., saving or drowning the Linux desktop?
item.description: Desktop Linux will take off next year -- or so people have been saying for years. Do desktop containerization technologies like Flatpak make this more, or less, likely?

item.title: Command-line hacking: timezone conversions
item.description: Using 'date' and 'timedatectl' to build a utility to help with scheduling meetings in different timezones.

item.title: Command-line hacking: displaying a weather summary
item.description: How to use tools like curl, sed, and groff to retrieve a weather forecast from the BBC, and format it for the terminal.

item.title: Command-line hacking: creating a tide table
item.description: How to use Bash shell arithmetic to create a simple tide table

item.title: Command-line hacking: extracting audio metadata (tags)
item.description: How to use Bash shell techniques to extract metadata (tags) from various audio file formats.

item.title: Command-line hacking: querying an Internet radio database
item.description: Using Linux command-line utilities to query an on-line database of Internet radio stations.

item.title: Command-line hacking: paced breathing
item.description: Using a Linux Bash script to generate audio/visual cues for timing paced breathing exercises.

item.title: Command-line hacking: displaying news headlines in the manual viewer
item.description: How to use tools like curl and xsltproc to retrieve news headlines from the BBC, and display them using the manual viewer

item.title: Command-line hacking: Assigning folder icons to directories
item.description: How to use basic Bash constructs, along with the Gnome gio utility, to assign folder icons to a set of directories.

item.title: How Microsoft Windows killed the palmtop computer
item.description: 1999 was the golden year of palmtop computing. Within a couple of years, palmtops were obsolete. Why?

item.title: Using Podman to deploy an image directly to OpenShift 4
item.description: This article describes how to deploy a container image direct from a local repository to an OpenShift 4 cluster, and instantiate a pod based on that image.

item.title: Understanding Java's functional interfaces
item.description: Functional interfaces are allow Java programmers to write methods whose arguments are lambda functions. How does this work, and why would it be useful?

item.title: How to write a technical or scientific report
item.description: Some guidance, mostly for science and engineering students, on how to write a scientific or technical paper. I've updated this slightly to deal with the rise in web-based publication but, frankly, I don't think that different standards apply to electronic and print reporting.

item.title: Using the new pluggable active/passive management framework in Apache Artemis
item.description: The Apache ActiveMQ Artemis message broker holds out the possibility of real shared-nothing replication. The problem, though, lies in coordinating the active and passive brokers in the cluster. This article describes the new active/passive management framework, and how to use Apache Zookeeper as the source of authority on cluster roles.

item.title: Embedding resources into executables built using GCC
item.description: Sometimes it's helpful to be able to create an executable program that embeds all the data it needs, and provide that data as files. C/C++ do not provide any standard way to do this, but GCC has facilities that the developer can use.

item.title: You be the linker -- building "Hello, world" from scratch, in hexadecimal
item.description: This article describes how to write a trivial program for Linux using no compiler tools at all, but entering machine language directly in hexadecimal. Because we can.

item.title: Did aliens really talk to us in "binary code" at Rendelsham Forest?
item.description: It isn't often that coding theory can be used to evaluate a claim of a UFO encounter. Here is one instance where it can.

item.title: They don't make 'em like that any more: the Lenovo W520
item.description: In praise of an iconic laptop computer.

item.title: How problematic is resampling audio from 44.1 to 48 kHz?
item.description: Audio CDs were recorded using a 44.1 kHz sample rate that is found almost nowhere else. If we have to resample this audio to suit more modern equipment, how much loss of audio quality will there be?

item.title: Using the Qpid Proton C++ library to create a server for monitoring or telemetry data
item.description: Collecting sensor data, or low-level system status information, is a job that is often best done in C/C++. Distributing this kind of data to other system components in a way that is platform- and language-independent can be a challenge. This article suggests a way to do this use AMQP message distribution.

item.title: Why we only see one side of the moon -- the odd phenomenon of tidal locking
item.description: We only see one face of the moon from the Earth, and that isn't a coincidence. The same process that causes this effect also affects other celestial bodies, often in more interesting ways.

item.title: Why the energy cost or benefit of switching to DAB digital radio is hard to assess
item.description: The "big switch-off" of analogue radio services in the UK has been deferred repeatedly. One of the reasons for this is that the impact on energy efficiency is hard to assess. This article seeks to explain why.

item.title: Creating an "animated score" for demonstrating musical compositions on YouTube, etc
item.description: Animated musical scores are quite common on YouTube, for educational and promotional purposes. This article explains how to create one, using OpenShot and other Linux tools.

item.title: Why I won't be dumping DuckDuckGo over Ukraine
item.description: Does controlling web search rankings amount to censorship? Does it matter if it does?

item.title: cwordle -- A Wordle-like word-guessing game for CP/M
item.description: Building a CP/M implementation of the notorious Wordle game.

item.title: The peculiar Benford distribution
item.description: Benford's law or the first digit rule states that in many data sets, the first digit of each value tends to be small. This is not at all obvious, but it has significant implications.

item.title: UTF-8 and the problem of over-long characters
item.description: How an oddity in the way UTF-8 encoding works can cause all sorts of problems for unwary developers, including security weaknesses.

item.title: Juice-jacking -- it's a problem, but not because it's a problem
item.description: "Juice-jacking" is the alleged practice of getting unauthorized access to the contents of a cellphone by subverting public USB charging points. It doesn't happen, and probably never has; so why has there been a recent increase in scare stories?

item.title: How Unicode reading direction characters defeat source code inspection, and what it means for the open-source movement
item.description: There's been a recent scare that Unicode reading direction characters could be used to conceal malicious code in open-source projects. This is undoubtedly true, but that fact doesn't make it significantly harder to ensure the security of open-source code than it already is.

item.title: Log4J -- ask yourself: do I really need that library?
item.description: What can the software industry learn from the Log4J security debacle?

item.title: Multi-source Z80 assembly programming for CP/M
item.description: How to use Microsoft's Macro80 and Link80 utilities on CP/M, to build a program consisting of multiple assembly-language files.
